hero.subtitle: When your RopeAccess vendors use OnRopePro, residents submit complaints directly to them. You stay informed without being the middleman. Free access to vendor safety ratings, response times, and complaint resolution data. No cost. No catch. Just freedom.

hook.question: How many resident complaints did you relay to vendors last month?
hook.problem: Every streaky window, every scheduling question, every "when are they coming to my side of the building?" lands on your desk first. You forward it. You follow up. You relay the response. You're the middleman for every issue on every building you manage.
hook.solution: What if complaints went directly to your vendor instead?
hook.description: When your vendors use OnRopePro, residents submit feedback straight to them. You see everything: what was reported, when it was viewed, how fast it was resolved. But you're not in the middle of it anymore.
hook.tagline: Oversight without involvement. That's the Property Manager Portal.

features.title: Out of the Complaint Loop. Into the Know.

directComplaints.title: Residents Complain Directly to Vendors. Not to You.
directComplaints.p1: When your vendors use OnRopePro, residents get access to a Resident Portal. They submit complaints with photos directly to the maintenance company. The vendor responds. The issue gets resolved.
directComplaints.p2: You're not in the middle of it. You're not the relay. You're not spending your Tuesday forwarding emails and making follow-up calls.
directComplaints.p3: But you see everything. Every complaint. Every response. Every resolution. Complete visibility without being the middleman.
directComplaints.p4: For a property manager handling 50 buildings, this is the difference between drowning in complaint coordination and actually managing properties.

responseTime.title: Response Time Metrics: The Accountability You've Been Missing
responseTime.p1: When residents complain directly to vendors, vendors can ignore them. Or they can respond in 24 hours. Now you know which.
responseTime.p2: The Property Manager Portal shows average resolution times and feedback response rates for every contractor. When you see a vendor taking 12 days to respond while another resolves issues in 2 days, you have data for your next contract conversation.
responseTime.p3: This is what Tommy (our co-founder, 15 years in rope access) says property managers care about most: "This will be a bigger factor than safety ratings. Are they actually responding to complaints?"

safetyRatings.title: Vendor Safety Ratings: Know Before Something Goes Wrong
safetyRatings.p1: Every rope access company on OnRopePro has a Company Safety Rating (CSR) built from three compliance metrics: documentation completeness, toolbox meeting frequency, and harness inspection rates.
safetyRatings.p2: You see exactly where each vendor stands. No guessing. No asking for reports they can fabricate.
safetyRatings.p3: When an insurance adjuster asks "What did you know about this vendor's safety practices?", you have an answer.

vendorDashboard.title: All Your Vendors. One Dashboard.
vendorDashboard.p1: Managing 20 buildings with different contractors? Finding which company services which building shouldn't require digging through emails and contracts.
vendorDashboard.p2: The My Vendors Dashboard shows every contracted rope access company, their safety scores, their response times, and which of your buildings they service. Thirty seconds instead of twenty minutes.

feedbackHistory.title: Feedback History Per Building
feedbackHistory.p1: That resident who complained about streaky windows three times? Track the entire conversation. See when the vendor responded, what they said, how long resolution took.
feedbackHistory.p2: Building-by-building complaint and resolution history gives you documentation when performance conversations get difficult. Or when you're deciding whether to renew a contract.

anchorInspection.title: Anchor Inspection Certificate Upload
anchorInspection.p1: Annual anchor inspections are required for rope access work. You receive the certificate from the third-party inspector. Now you have one place to store it.
anchorInspection.p2: Upload anchor inspection certificates directly to each building record. Your only write permission. Everything else is read-only for data integrity.

comparison.title: Before vs. After: Where Complaints Go

before.title: Before OnRopePro
before.summary: You're the relay. Every complaint, every update, every follow-up routes through your inbox. Multiply by 50 buildings. That's your week.

after.title: With OnRopePro
after.step2: Resident submits directly to Vendor (with photos)
after.whereAreYou: Where are you in this flow?
after.watching: Watching from your dashboard. You see every complaint that comes in, when it was viewed, how long resolution took. If a vendor is ignoring complaints, you'll know. If they're responding in 24 hours, you'll see that too.
after.notMiddle: But you're not in the middle of it. You're not the relay. You're not spending hours on complaint coordination.
after.oversight: You're the property manager with oversight. Not the complaint department.

howItWorks.title: Three Steps. Five Minutes. Free Forever.

step1.title: Get Your Property Manager Code
step1.description: Ask your rope access vendor for a Property Manager Code. Any company using OnRopePro can generate one for you. Takes them 30 seconds.

step2.title: Create Your Free Account
step2.description: Enter the code, create your account, and specify which buildings you manage. No credit card. No trial period. Free access. Period.

step3.title: Watch Your Workload Shrink
step3.description: View safety ratings, response metrics, and complaint resolution data for every vendor servicing your buildings. See complaints being handled without your involvement. Compare contractors objectively. Make informed decisions.

howItWorks.footer: When residents in your buildings start using the Resident Portal, complaints stop routing through you. You just see the results.

whyFree.title: Yes, It's Actually Free. Here's Why.
whyFree.p1: Your vendors pay for OnRopePro. You don't.
whyFree.p2: When property managers can see vendor safety ratings, contractors have powerful motivation to maintain high scores. Companies with strong safety records get more work. Companies with poor records lose contracts.
whyFree.p3: That transparency benefits everyone: safer work for technicians, better vendor selection for you, documented compliance for insurance purposes.
whyFree.p4: Your access isn't the product. Your visibility is what makes the product valuable.

documentation.title: The Documentation You'll Wish You Had. Before You Need It.
documentation.p1: Insurance audits. Liability claims. Board inquiries. Regulatory inspections.
documentation.p2: They all ask the same question: "What did you know about your vendor's safety practices?"
documentation.p3: The Property Manager Portal creates an automatic audit trail. Every time you check a vendor's CSR, view their response metrics, or compare contractors, that visibility is documented.
documentation.p4: When someone asks what due diligence you performed, you have an answer.
documentation.p5: When a competitor's building has an incident and the news asks "Could this happen here?", you have data showing exactly how your vendors compare.

timeBack.title: What Would You Do With 10 Extra Hours a Week?
timeBack.p1: Property managers managing 30+ buildings spend 8-15 hours weekly on complaint coordination alone. Forwarding emails. Following up with vendors. Relaying responses. Chasing updates.
timeBack.p2: When complaints go directly to vendors:
timeBack.p3: Those hours disappear from your workload.
timeBack.p4: You still have full visibility. You still see response times. You still have documentation for board meetings and contract renewals. You just don't have to be the middleman anymore.
timeBack.p5: That's time back for lease renewals. For tenant relations. For the strategic work that actually grows your portfolio. For leaving at 5pm instead of 7pm.
timeBack.p6: The Property Manager Portal doesn't just give you data. It gives you your time back.

accountability.title: When Vendors Know You're Watching, Everything Changes.
accountability.p1: Here's what happens when you can see vendor response times:
accountability.p2: The vendor who takes 12 days to respond to complaints knows you can see that. The vendor who resolves issues in 48 hours knows you can see that too.
accountability.p3: An 86% safety rating versus a 23% safety rating tells a story. A 2-day average resolution time versus a 14-day average tells another.
accountability.p4: When property managers can see these numbers, vendors can't hide behind vague assurances. The companies doing the work right finally have proof. The companies cutting corners or ignoring complaints get exposed.
accountability.p5: Your visibility creates accountability. When vendors know their response times affect their contracts, responsiveness becomes a competitive advantage.
accountability.p6: Better for residents. Better for you. Better for everyone who lives and works in your buildings.

q1.question: "What if my vendors don't use OnRopePro?"
q1.a1: Ask them about it. Vendors who prioritize safety and responsiveness want property managers to see their ratings and resolution times. If they resist transparency, that tells you something.
q1.a2: You can also tell them: "I'd like to stop being the complaint relay between residents and your company. OnRopePro lets residents submit directly to you, and I get visibility into response times."
q1.a3: Most vendors will see that as a benefit, not a burden.

q2.question: "What if residents keep complaining to me anyway?"
q2.a1: Redirect them. "Submit your feedback through the Resident Portal. The vendor will see it immediately and respond directly. I can see everything you submit, but they'll respond faster if you go directly."
q2.a2: Most residents prefer direct access over waiting for you to relay messages. The system trains the behavior quickly.

q3.question: "I don't want to lose visibility into what's happening at my buildings."
q3.a2: You see every complaint that comes in, when it was viewed, when it was resolved, what the vendor said. You have complete visibility into the entire conversation.
q3.a3: You just don't have to be IN the conversation anymore. Oversight without involvement.

q4.question: "I already track vendor certificates in spreadsheets."
q4.a1: Certificates confirm insurance exists. They don't tell you if workers are actually following safety protocols. CSR shows real-time compliance, not paperwork.
q4.a2: And spreadsheets don't route complaints directly to vendors. They don't show you response time metrics. They don't give you the data you need for contract decisions.

q5.question: "This seems too good to be free."
q5.a1: Your vendors pay for the platform. Your access creates the visibility that makes their investment valuable. There's no catch because you're not the customer. You're the accountability mechanism that makes the system work.

q6.question: "I need to check with my portfolio manager first."
q6.a1: Show them this page. The ROI argument writes itself:
q6.a2: Free access. Complaint elimination. Vendor accountability data. Liability documentation. No budget required.

finalCta.title: Oversight Without Involvement. Visibility Without Burden.
finalCta.subtitle1: Complaints go directly to vendors. You see everything without being in the middle.
finalCta.subtitle2: Safety ratings show real compliance. Response times prove accountability.
finalCta.free: Free. No credit card. No trial expiration.

problemStatement.title: Tired of Complaints That Go Nowhere?
problemStatement.paragraph1: You email the property manager about streaks on your window. A week passes. Nothing. You call. They say they forwarded it to the vendor. The vendor says they never got it.
problemStatement.paragraph2: Now three people are involved in tracking down one email that may or may not have been sent.
problemStatement.paragraph3: Meanwhile, you see crews working on the building but have no idea if they've reached your side yet. You call again. Turns out they finished your floor yesterday.
problemStatement.solution: The Resident Portal puts you in direct contact with the service company working on your building. Submit once. See when it was viewed. Track it through to resolution.

whatYouCanDo.subtitle: The Resident Portal gives you direct access to project updates and a documented communication channel with the service team.

trackProgress.item4: No more premature "you missed my window" calls

step1.title: Create Your Account
step1.description: Sign up with your email, strata plan number, and unit number. This links your account to your specific building and unit. Takes about two minutes.

step2.description: Your building manager or property manager provides a vendor code. Enter it once in your profile to connect with the service company working on your building.

step3.label: Step 3

step3.description: Your dashboard shows active projects on your building. View progress. Submit feedback. Track responses. Everything in one place.

note.text: Your account stays with you. If you move to a different building, update your strata number and enter the new vendor's code. No need to start over.

problem1.trigger: "My complaint disappeared into a black hole."
problem1.description: You submitted feedback via email or phone. Days pass. No response. You follow up. They can't find it. You explain the whole thing again. Still nothing.
problem1.solution: With the Resident Portal, every submission is logged with a timestamp. You see the exact date and time the company opened your feedback. "I didn't see it" becomes impossible when you can prove they viewed it on Tuesday at 2:47 PM.

problem2.description: Phone to property manager. Property manager to vendor. Vendor to technician. Somewhere along the way, "water stain on bedroom window" became "balcony glass issue." The tech arrives confused.
problem2.solution: Submit once through the portal. Your name, unit, phone, and description are captured. Attach photos. Done. The team sees exactly what you see. No telephone game.

problem3.trigger: "I have no idea if they've done my window yet."
problem3.description: Crews are on the building. You can see them from the street. But are they on the north side or south? Did they finish your floor yesterday or is it scheduled for next week?
problem3.solution: The portal shows real-time progress by elevation. You know your side hasn't been touched yet. You wait. No wasted calls asking "are you done?"

problem4.trigger: "They said they'd fix it but nothing changed."
problem4.description: Feedback submitted. Response received. Issue marked closed. But nothing actually improved. Now what?
problem4.solution: You can see the status history and any responses from the team. If the issue persists after closure, contact your building manager with documented proof of what was communicated.

faq1.question: How do I get the vendor code?
faq1.answer: Contact your building manager or property manager. They receive the vendor code from the service company and share it with residents.

faq2.question: Can I access the portal from my phone?
faq2.answer: Yes. The portal works on any device with internet access: phone, tablet, or computer.

faq3.question: What if I move to a different unit in the same building?
faq3.answer: Update your unit number in your account settings. Your strata plan number stays the same.

faq4.question: What if I move to a different building?
faq4.answer: Update both your strata plan number and unit number. Enter the new vendor's code when you receive it from your new building manager.

faq5.question: Can other residents see my feedback?
faq5.answer: No. You can only see feedback you submitted. Building managers and the service company can see all feedback for the building, but other residents cannot.

faq6.question: What happens if my feedback is closed but the issue persists?
faq6.answer: Only the company can reopen closed feedback. If you believe an issue wasn't fully resolved, contact your building manager or property manager with documented proof from the portal.

faq7.question: Can I submit positive feedback?
faq7.answer: Absolutely. The system accepts all types of input: concerns, compliments, questions, and suggestions.

faq8.question: How long do I have to submit feedback after work is done?
faq8.answer: Residents have 5 business days after project completion to submit feedback. This window allows time to notice issues while keeping the complaint period reasonable.

faq9.question: Is my data secure?
faq9.answer: Yes. Your account uses encrypted passwords and secure sessions. Your feedback is private and visible only to you and authorized personnel.

hero.badge: Raising the Bar for an Entire Industry
hero.title: Safety Is Either Measured
hero.description3: When both are visible, the entire industry gets safer.
hero.freeNote: Free for technicians. Always. 14-day trial for companies.

problem.title: Safety Theater vs. Safety Culture
problem.intro: Most rope access companies talk about safety. Some have binders full of procedures sitting in the office. A few actually follow them.
problem.p1: The problem is nobody can tell the difference. A technician interviewing at two companies hears the same pitch: "We take safety seriously." One company does daily harness inspections, holds real toolbox meetings, and makes sure everyone understands the procedures. The other company hands you gear and says "don't fall."
problem.p2: A property manager evaluating bids sees the same safety claims in every proposal. Everyone has a "comprehensive safety program." Nobody can prove it. Price becomes the only differentiator.
problem.solution: OnRopePro changes the equation by making safety measurable, portable, and visible. Not safety claims. Safety actions. Documented, timestamped, aggregated into scores that follow technicians and companies everywhere they go.

scores.title: Two Scores That Change Everything
scores.subtitle: When these scores matter, behavior changes.
scores.subtitle2: When behavior changes, people actually go home safe.

psr.title: PSR: Personal Safety Rating
psr.description: Your individual safety record, aggregated across every employer you've ever worked for on OnRopePro.
psr.item1: How often you complete harness inspections
psr.item2: How quickly you acknowledge safety documents
psr.item3: Your compliance rate over time, not just today
psr.footer: Your PSR is portable. It belongs to you, not your employer. When you apply for a new job, employers see your safety rating before they hire you.

csr.title: CSR: Company Safety Rating
csr.description: Your company's safety culture, calculated from operational data across four categories.
csr.footer: CSR is visible to property managers. When they compare bids, they're comparing 86% versus 43%. Green badge versus red badge.

flywheel.title: OnRopePro Is Giving Safety a Value
flywheel.subtitle: A self-reinforcing cycle where everyone wins by prioritizing safety.
flywheel.intro1: Safety has always been theoretical. Companies say the right words. Techs nod along. Nobody measures anything. Nothing changes.
flywheel.intro2: We're making safety practical. Measurable. Tradeable. When a technician's PSR affects their job prospects, they care about their inspections. When a company's CSR affects their contract wins, they invest in their culture. When property managers choose vendors by safety score, the market rewards the right behavior.
flywheel.intro3: This isn't compliance software. This is infrastructure that makes safety worth something. The entire industry rises because the incentives finally align.

stage1.title: Technicians Start Caring About Their Score
stage1.description: When PSR follows you everywhere, you start paying attention. That harness inspection you used to skip when you were "in a hurry"? It affects your score. Suddenly, safety isn't something the boss nags you about. It's your professional reputation. It's career capital.

stage2.title: Employers Hire Based on PSR
stage2.description: A technician applies with a 92% PSR. Another applies with a 58% PSR. Same certifications. Similar experience. Which one do you trust with your company's reputation? Employers start filtering for high-PSR candidates. The message spreads: if you want the good jobs, maintain your rating.

stage3.title: High-PSR Techs Raise Company Standards
stage3.description: When you hire people who take safety seriously, your company culture shifts. They do their inspections without being reminded. They sign documents promptly. They hold each other accountable. Your CSR rises because your team is actually doing the work.

stage4.title: Property Managers Choose High-CSR Vendors
stage4.description: Two bids on the table. Similar pricing. One vendor shows 91% CSR. The other shows 52% CSR. The property manager has liability concerns. The board asks questions. The high-CSR vendor wins. Not because they talked better. Because they proved they're better.

stage5.title: Market Pressure Forces Industry Improvement
stage5.description: Companies losing bids to high-CSR competitors have a choice: improve or keep losing. The cowboys who undercut on price while cutting corners find themselves locked out of quality contracts.
stage5.conclusion: The industry standard rises. Not because of regulation. Because the incentives aligned.

technicians.title: For Technicians
technicians.item2: Your safety record protects you in incidents
technicians.quote: "Would you rather work for a company with a 40 CSR or a 95 CSR? Your life is on the line."

employers.title: For Company Owners
employers.item1: Win contracts you used to lose
employers.quote: "I know all my people have read this document because they've signed it."

propertyManagers.title: For Property Managers
propertyManagers.quote: "They have a 92% CSR. Their documentation is complete and current."

whyMatters.title: Why This Matters Beyond Business
whyMatters.subtitle: The real goal: people going home safe.
whyMatters.p1: Rope access is dangerous work. Falls kill. Equipment failures kill. Skipped procedures kill.
whyMatters.p2: The industry talks about safety because everyone knows the stakes. But talking isn't enough. Systems that enforce safety are what actually protect people.
whyMatters.psrPointDesc: about their own safety practices because those practices now affect their careers.
whyMatters.csrPointDesc: about their safety culture because that culture now affects their revenue.
whyMatters.pmPointDesc: makes the market reward safety because vendors with high CSR win contracts.
whyMatters.conclusion1: When incentives align with safety, safety happens.
whyMatters.conclusion3: As the foundation of how the industry operates.

newPsr.question: What if I've never used OnRopePro before? Do I start with a zero PSR?
newPsr.answer: New technicians start building their PSR from their first inspection. There's no penalty for being new. Your score reflects your actual history on the platform.

fakeInspection.question: Can I fake a harness inspection just to keep my score up?
fakeInspection.answer: No. The system requires you to step through each equipment category. Failed items automatically retire in inventory. The process takes 30 seconds when done honestly. Gaming it would take longer and create equipment management problems.

psrEmployer.question: What happens to my PSR if my employer has a low CSR?
psrEmployer.answer: Your PSR is independent. It tracks your individual compliance, not your employer's overall score. A disciplined tech working for a disorganized company still builds strong PSR through their own actions.

newCompany.question: We're a new company. Won't we be at a disadvantage with a short history?
newCompany.answer: New companies can reach 100% CSR immediately by uploading core documents and maintaining daily compliance. History matters for weathering occasional lapses, but new companies with disciplined practices quickly build competitive scores.

pmSeePsr.question: Do property managers see individual technician ratings?
pmSeePsr.answer: No. Property managers see company CSR only. Individual PSR is visible to employers during hiring, not to external parties.

disagreeCsr.question: What if I disagree with my CSR calculation?
disagreeCsr.answer: The dashboard shows exactly where you're losing points. If documentation shows 85% but you believe you're at 100%, you can see exactly which documents are missing signatures. The system doesn't hide its logic.

surveillance.question: This seems like surveillance. Is it?
surveillance.answer: It's accountability. The same way a pilot's flight hours and certifications are tracked, your professional safety actions are tracked. This protects you when things go wrong. It builds your reputation when things go right. Your data belongs to you and travels with you.

cta.title: Start Building Your Safety Record Today
cta.description: Your safety practices are either measured or they're made up. Start measuring.
cta.freeNote: Free for technicians. Always. 14-day trial for companies. No credit card required.

q1.question: How do I get access to the Building Portal?
q1.answer: Your account is created automatically when a rope access company using OnRopePro starts a project on your building. You'll receive access credentials via email, or you can log in using your strata/plan number as both username and password.

q2.question: What can I see in the Building Portal?
q2.answer: You can view real-time work progress, resident feedback, work notices, project history, and all safety documentation. You can also update building access instructions for technicians.

q3.question: Can I communicate with the rope access company?
q3.answer: Yes! You can view company contact information, access resident complaints that have been submitted, and review work notices. The vendor company can see your building access instructions and special requirements.

q4.question: How do I update building access instructions?
q4.answer: In the Building Instructions section, you can update access codes, key fob information, roof access details, and any special requests. This information is shared with technicians working on your building.

q5.question: Is my building information secure?
q5.answer: Absolutely. All data is encrypted and only accessible to authorized users. Building managers can only see projects associated with their specific building. We recommend changing your password from the default immediately after first login.
